department: Department of Applied Psychology and Human Development
application_procedure: All applications must be received by August 7, 2024. To be considered for this position, please include 1. One-page cover letter outlining what the applicant brings to the position; 2. Current Curriculum Vitae; 3. Course Evaluations of all recent courses taught, if applicable. If you are a current/former U of T Sessional and require assistance retrieving your course evaluations, please contact your department ahead of the application deadline; 4. Names of referees may also be included but are not required. Applications should be sent to aphdsessional.oise@utoronto.ca, APHD Chair, Department of Applied Psychology and Human Development, OISE 252 Bloor St. West, Toronto, ON M5S 1V6. If during the application and/or selection process, you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact aphdsessional.oise@utoronto.ca.
duties: Instructors are required to: 1. Teach a minimum of 36 hours; 2. Prepare teaching resources for each class and provide relevant materials; 3. Assess and evaluate students' work and provide a final grade according to OISE/UT grading practices; 4. Be available for informal meetings/communications with students as necessary.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: 1. Candidate must be working towards a doctoral degree in psychology or a related field; 2. Expertise in content area; 3. Experience conducting and/or knowledge of play research and implementation of play in educational settings.
qualifications_preferred: 1. Preference will be given to individuals with demonstrated expertise with related course content; 2. Prior experience teaching graduate courses prefered; 3. Demonstrated scholarship in the area of the course topic.
salery: Minimum stipend is $8,142.51 (per half course, excludes vacation pay) for a half (F/S) course.

department: Centre for the Study of the United States
application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter, C.V. (including previous teaching evaluations (if applicable)), and a list of references by August 12, 2024. Applications should be sent electronically to Professor Leah Montange at 20TUleah.montange@utoronto.caU20T with a CC to csus@utoronto.ca.
duties:
•	Marking/grading student papers and assignments
•	Calculation and submission of grades
•	Attend classes throughout the semester
•	Holding office hours for academic counselling of students (including electronic consultation)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Teaching experience in grading, preferably in American-focused courses, as well as an Americanist research focus are preferred. First consideration will be given to full-time graduate students at the University of Toronto.

application_procedure: Applications should be made, with current curriculum vitae, proposed course outline, teaching statement, evidence of teaching effectiveness and a list of references. Application materials should be submitted to the attention of Prof. Michelle Silver, Chair, Department of Health Studies, University of Toronto Scarborough, 1265 Military Trail, Toronto, Ontario M1C1A4. All applications must be submitted to the Online Teaching Application at: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/chs/app/instr.
duties: Please note that classes will be held in person. All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; supervising TAs, holding regular office hours.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants’ research area and qualifications should be closely related to course material. Demonstrated ability to design syllabus in accordance with department guidelines. Ability to coordinate multiple tutorials, lectures to large classes, explain a variety of methodologies to an undergraduate student body.  Evidence of progress in the Ph.D. program.

application_procedure: Applicants should submit their applications by email to spanport.search@utoronto.ca, with the course code in the subject line. Applications must include a cover letter describing briefly the applicant's approach to the course, a list of proposed texts, 3 previous course evaluations, and a CV. All these documents should be submitted as one single PDF document.
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a University credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; holding regular office hours; order all necessary readings.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates must be in a PhD in Spanish Literature or related field. Must have substantive teaching experience in Spanish, and evidence of expertise in the specific area of the course.

application_procedure: Fill out application form found here (https://moleculargenetics.utoronto.ca/teaching-assistantships-ta) and send CV to studentservices.mogen@utoronto.ca
duties: Current aspects of human and molecular genetics including: human genome/chromosome/gene structure and function, epigenetics, comparative genomics, rare and complex disease mechanisms, human disease modelling, population genetics, genome wide association studies, cancer genetics, genetic testing and the genome clinic, genetic disease treatment, and ethical questions in clinical genetics. This course is taught by expert faculty and assumes solid background knowledge in classical genetics, gene structure and function, biochemistry, and cell biology.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications: Applicants will be considered on the basis of their familiarity with bioinformatics practices in the molecular biology research lab using the R Programming language & must have completed undergraduate training in this area, or have gained equivalent experience through research project work.  Further details about the Department’s hiring policy are available in the Department & the CUPE office.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants will be considered on the basis of their practical familiarity with human genetics, population genetics, and genomics. This would include population genetics in other species, cancer genetics, DNA repair, modeling human disease, mammalian-genome related bioinformatics, as gained through some combination of coursework & research project work. Further details about the Department’s hiring policy are available in the Department & CUPE office.

qualifications_minimum: Successful applicants must be enrolled in a MA program in Religion or a related field; be competent in the subject matter of the class; and have organizational and communication skills necessary for the fulfillment of their duties.
qualifications_preferred: Successful applicants must have advanced training or graduate education in Religion; be competent in the subject matter of the class; and have organizational and communication skills necessary for the fulfillment of their duties.

duties:
Responsible for providing one-on-one or group support to students in beginning and intermediate LGG-Chinese courses.
Provide 2 hour/ week availability. Duties are completed in-person at UTSC.
Schedule to be determined in conjunction with Program Coordinator


Note: The number of hours are an estimate and are tentative pending enrolment numbers.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Graduate student who has completed the ECT program or related program of study/ experience. Successfully completed a number of upper year (C and D-level) LGG-Chinese courses with a grade of A or higher. Native or near native speaker of Mandarin.
qualifications_preferred: Experience as a language lab monitor or language cafes will be considered an asset.

application_procedure: Please apply here: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/lin
duties: Attending lectures at the discretion of the instructor to help troubleshoot with students and assist with the delivery of content in class. Grading, invigilating, and entering grades. Note: while the incumbent will not be expected to attend every lecture, they will be expected to attend certain lectures at the discretion of the instructor, and will need to guarantee availability at all lecture times. Travel to the the Scarborough campus for attending lecture, meeting with the instructor, picking up and returning assignments/test/exams, and invigilating is mandatory and invigilating is mandatory. Note: The number of hours are an estimate and are tentative pending enrolment numbers.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Graduate student (Ph.D. in progress) in Linguistics, Psychology, Neuroscience or related field with a focus on language and the brain/neurolinguistics. Knowledge of R and statistics is necessary.  Experience grading, and communicating with students (emails/ classroom setting).
qualifications_preferred: Knowledge of brain imaging methods and EEG data analysis desirable but not essential. The relevant criterion is having prior experience.

application_procedure: A complete application, assembled in a SINGLE pdf, must include (i) a cover letter that outlines your relevant teaching experience, and (ii) your resume. This pdf file must be submitted to  director.engsci@utoronto.ca with the subject line "ESC101 CI Application" by the specified closing date of the posting.  If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Diane Giang at director.engsci@utoronto.ca.
duties: Duties include: Working with the core teaching team to develop lecture content and studio materials; attending all lectures throughout the term; attending two weekly meetings; attending a day long orientation session for all instructors at the beginning of term (date TBA, likely late August); supporting  studios for the duration of the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
P.Eng
Experience teaching Engineering Design
qualifications_preferred: Strong performance as an instructor in Praxis I or II. Flexible availability for studio and benchmarking meetings is also preferred.
salery: In accordance with the current CUPE 3902, Unit 1 collective agreement, the rate of pay applicable for course instructors will be $9,094.13 per half course or $10,163.28 for first CI appointment per half course (includes additional stipend)
tutorial:
Lectures M 13–14, T 9–10, F 11–12 (lecturers are expected to attend two of three each week) 

Tutorials (Studios) T 10–12, T 14–16, R 14–16, R 16–18 (lecturers are responsible for two each week, schedule TBD).  

Weekly Teaching Team meeting M 14–15.  

Weekly Debrief Meeting T 12–13.

application_procedure:
Applicants must submit a cover letter and updated C.V. (including information as to teaching and marking experience by clearly listing course titles, course codes, and sessions [terms and years]) to italian.admin@utoronto.ca and italian.undergrad@utoronto.ca by August 2, 2024. The cover letter must address qualifications and the duties listed.

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact italian.admin@utoronto.ca.
This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. The position above is tentative, pending final course determinations and enrolments.
The Departmental Hiring Policy is available in the Department office, online at https://www.italianstudies.utoronto.ca/sites/www.italianstudies.utoronto.ca/files/ITA%20Statement%20of%20Hiring%20Policy%20CUPE%203902%20Unit%201%202020.pdf, and in the CUPE Local 3902 office.

The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodations at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoft.careers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at U of T, please visit our Accommodation webpage.
The hiring criteria for Course Instructors positions are academic qualifications, the need to acquire experience, previous teaching experience and previous satisfactory employment under the provisions of this Collective Agreement.
The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas.

Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position.

This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. 

The position(s) posted above is (are) tentative, pending final course determinations and enrolments.

Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies, Postdoctoral Fellows and Undergraduate Students in the University of Toronto.
duties: Duties include course preparation and delivery of course content designed for a multi-sectional course; helping in preparation of tests, assignments, and exams, in collaboration with the course coordinator and other instructors in the course, if required; administering written and oral assignments, tests, and exams according to a shared schedule across all course sections; marking and assessing written and oral assignments, tests, exams, and class participation according to shared evaluation rubrics and according to commonality of standards; calculating and submitting grades; holding  regular office hours; managing class and grades on a shared course management site; and attending course administrative meetings as required; producing one to three asynchronous video for all sections of the course.

qualifications_minimum:
• Native or near native proficiency in Italian is required.
• Demonstrable skills in explaining grammar concepts clearly and concisely with relevant Italian examples are required.
• Demonstrable skills to correct and assess students’ written and oral work.

• Some previous experience in teaching Italian language for beginners is required.

duties: The duties of Course Instuctors shall include the normal duties associated with the design and teaching of university degree credit courses or sections of courses. duties:
“- Delivering the lectures in-person as scheduled.
- Maintaining course administration including: course website on quercus, marking schemes, lectures, tutorials, assignments, tests, and final assessments.
- Providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students, through office hours, email, the course website and/or the course bulletin board.
- Preparing the breakdown of hours for TA duties in the course and supervising the TAs.
- Ensuring that tutorials and/or labs are delivered appropriately by the TAs.
- Managing the grading for the course, which is largely done by the TAs, and carrying out any grading not handled by the TAs.
- Managing the grades and submitting final course grades, including the timely completion and release of grades and feedback to students throughout the term
- Invigilating the final exam if applicable. 
- As there are other sections of the same course that term, coordinating with the other instructor(s) to maintain consistency (this includes using common assignments and a common final exam); 
- where relevant, instructors must work together to coordinate automarking of assignments.

While there is a lot of room for creativity in course delivery, instructors will be expected to follow the basic content and style used by the faculty members who normally teach the course, and must get approval from these faculty members or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate on any substantial changes to the course content or assessment methods. Instructors will also be expected to consult with the department's Teaching Support group when creating the course syllabus, final exam, and test(s).
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

- demonstrated expertise in topic area of the course
- strong organizational, interpersonal, and communication skills
- previous experience as a course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset
- demonstrated evidence of excellence in Teaching an asset

The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodations at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoftccareers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the
University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at U of T, please visit our Accommodation webpage.

The hiring criteria for Course Instructors positions are academic qualifications, the need to acquire experience, previous teaching experience and previous satisfactory employment under the provisions of this Collective Agreement.

The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas.
Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position.
This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement.
The position(s) posted above is (are) tentative, pending final course determinations and enrolments.

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references to typ.office@utoronto.ca by August 1, 2024  at 5 PM.
duties: The Teaching Assistant will support the course instructor in the instruction and management of TYP024H1F (Equity and Solidarity in Education), a compulsory course at the Transitional Year Program at University of Toronto. This course offers interdiscplinary and intersectional exploration of systemic inequities, and social justice issues in education, both locally and globally. Delving into major concepts, historical perspectives, key debates, and grassroot resistance to inequity and oppression it provides the foundation for a critical engagement with equity and solidarity in education. Through a focused examination of theory and practice, this course provides insights intro diverse thoughts and and methods for fostering transformational change within educational change. The Teaching Assistant (TA) will support the course instructor in the general instruction and management of the course. The TA will help to lead a classes that support TYP students in their development of academic and life skills, including note-taking, the writing process, research, organization, and other related skills. The TA will evaluate student work, provide feedback, schedule and hold office hours,  provide academic support for course assignments, and lead discussions, and manage the course Quercus. Additional duties will be determined in consultation with the course instructor and registrar. The TA may be required to attend seminars, lectures, and meetings. Please note, this course will be offered in person, with online elements (i.e. Quercus). For more information about TYP, please visit typ.utoronto.ca.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be purusing a graduate or undergraduate degree in Equity Studies, Sociology, or a related discipline. Preference in hiring shall be given to Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. The candidate must demonstrate a commitment to equity and anti-oppressive/social-justice approaches to education and familiarity with Quercus and online instructional methods.
qualifications_preferred: The candidate must have: (a) Previous work experience and/ or coursework relating to equity and educational access, anti-oppression, and social-justice approaches to post-secondary education.                                          (b) In-depth knowledge of the University of Toronto community and student experience.                                         (c) Knowledge of/ or experience with adult education and the University of Toronto Transitional Year Program or similar programming. (d)Experience advising students and providing writing support in the social sciences and/ or humanities. Shortlisted candidates may be asked to complete a brief written screening question and/or an interview.

application_procedure:

Rebecca Bi
Program Administrator and Communications Officer
Asian Institute, Munk School of Global Affairs & Public Policy
University of Toronto
ai.asianstudies@utoronto.ca

YOU MUST USE THE FOLLOWING FOR YOUR SUBJECT LINE: APPLICATION: COURSE CODE: LAST NAME. Please attach your C.V. and cover letter as PDFs, and label your attachments as follows: Last Name_First Name_Cover; Last Name_First Name_CV.
duties:
• Developing syllabus

experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.

job_title: Representing Science and Technology in Popular Media
application_procedure:
Please visit https://ecp.engineering.utoronto.ca/job-opportunities/application-procedures-cupe-unit-1-positions/ for details on the application 
procedure. 

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Chanelle Small-Reid at istep.academic@utoronto.ca.
duties: Teaching Assistant will help with course preparation, assessment, and delivery. Preparation duties may involve setting up Quercus pages, lecture content, and assignments. Assesment duties will involve providing feedback on student  assignments - oral presentations, short papers, or scientific articles. Delivery may involve leading in class discussions, or reporting on current trends or research in science communication.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Must be at least enrolled in the later years of a BA or BASC in  a discipline such as Engineering, IHPST, or Communication Studies.   Must be able to adapt and respond to unexpected classroom situations, express, argue and defend opinions to both students and instructors and demonstrate strong communication skills in oral and written forms. Must have demonstrated experience with the history, theory and practice  of science communication, either through classes, extracurricular or industry experience  or research.
qualifications_preferred: Experience as a student or TA in engineering communication courses, including TEP321,  is desirable.
salery: $52.97 per hour + vacation pay (as of Jan 1, 2025). Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Please visit https://ecp.engineering.utoronto.ca/job-opportunities/application-procedures-cupe-unit-1-positions/ for details on the application procedure.
duties:
Attending a one-hour instructional team meeting per week 
Attending up to six lectures per term 
Supervising 14-16 student teams (3 students per team) as project manager (30-minute meeting times to take place both within and outside of tutorial hours, 8-9 meetings per team over the term) 
Commenting on weekly team progress reports  
Meeting with students for consultation on request 
Facilitating practice oral presentations for the second oral presentation, and as needed through the term 
Grading a short individual explanation of a hardware component, a longer team design proposal, a midterm team oral presentation and a final team oral presentation 
Must be available  for a minimum of two pre-scheduled 2-hour tutorial slots plus one evening session during the week of the first oral presentation 
Must have the ability to adapt to different communication instruction activities and move online if required.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: "This course is an introduction to engineering design processes, illustrated through the design and implementation of a hardware system. In addition to familiarizing students with hardware design practices, tools, and skill sets, it also aims to develop effective oral and written communication in a team context. Principles of hardware design, project management and teamwork are developed in the lectures and tutorials, and students apply these concepts in the laboratories as they work in a team to design and implement a complex hardware system. Students learn and practice oral and written communication techniques in lectures and in meetings with their communication instructor and apply these techniques in a variety of documents and presentations, such as short status reports and longer design proposals and design reviews. Minimum Qualifications: include at least a Master’s degree in an appropriate discipline (such as, but not limited to, Communication, English, Engineering, Education, Technology Studies) with strong writing and oral communication skills, and a demonstrated commitment to teaching communication and demonstrated ability to work as part of a team. Flexible availability is a requirement for these positions. "
qualifications_preferred: include a PhD in an appropriate discipline (as above), TESL or CESLA certificate (or equivalent in ESL specialization or development of ESL curricula), familiarity with engineering communication practices and/or experience as an instructor in first year foundation course, Engineering Strategies and Practice. Also considered assets are experience in curriculum development, tutoring and/or working with a diverse group of students.
salery: In accordance with the current CUPE 3902, Unit 1 collective agreement, the rate of pay applicable for course instructors will be $$9,276.01 (excludes vacation pay) per half course and $19,642.56 (excludes vacation pay) per full course.
tutorial: Students attend two one-hour lectures, one two-hour lab and one 30-minute meeting with a Communication Instructor.

Applicant should be comfortable with using technology such as Microsoft Teams or Zoom.

job_title: Gender and Genre in Italian Cinema
application_procedure: Applicants must submit a cover letter and updated C.V. by e-mail to italian.admin@utoronto.ca and italian.undergrad@utoronto.ca. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact italian.admin@utoronto.ca. This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. The position above is tentative, pending final course determinations and enrolments. The Departmental Hiring Policy is available in the Department office, online at https://www.italianstudies.utoronto.ca/sites/www.italianstudies.utoronto.ca/files/ITA%20Statement%20of%20Hiring%20Policy%20CUPE%203902%20Unit%201%202020.pdf, and in the CUPE Local 3902 office. The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodations at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoft.careers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at U of T, please visit our Accommodation webpage. The hiring criteria for Course Instructors positions are academic qualifications, the need to acquire experience, previous teaching experience and previous satisfactory employment under the provisions of this Collective Agreement. The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas. Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position. This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. The position(s) posted above is (are) tentative, pending final course determinations and enrolments. Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies, Postdoctoral Fellows and Undergraduate Students in the University of Toronto.
duties:
Course description: The course looks at Italian cinema from the perspective of gender and genre studies. While the focus will be primarily on film, the course will also engage with different media and discuss how these have informed and influenced Italian notions of masculinity and femininity throughout the Twentieth Century. The emphasis on genre will provide the structure to organize a discourse that will embrace very diverse and multifaceted texts, and will enable students to develop their analytical and critical skills in the field. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience. (Given in English)

Duties include course preparation and delivery of course content; designing and preparing tests, assignments, and exams; marking written and oral assignments, tests, and exams; calculating and submitting grades; holding regular office hours; if threshold of 50 students is met and TA is assigned, leading a Teaching Assistant in marking part of the assignments by providing clear marking rubrics and checking the correct application of them; and attending course administrative meetings as required
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: ABD in Italian Studies with a proven interest in Italian cinema required. -Experience teaching in a university environment required. -Relevant background in cinema studies. -Experience teaching Italian cinema or equivalent.
qualifications_preferred: Familiarity with the Italian language preferred.
ta_support: Contingent upon student enrolment (50 students required for TA support)
tutorial:
Mondays, 14:00 - 18:00
*Please note, this course is scheduled to be delivered in-person.

job_title: The Context of Mental Health & Health Practice
application_procedure: Please apply by email, with a cover letter and curriculum vitae to angela.umbrello@utoronto.ca
duties:
Teaching a course titled “The Context of Mental Health & Health Practice” based on the approved course outline.  The instructor must adhere to course policies on teaching and holding the course at the scheduled time.  The course content, notes, readings, and assignments are uniform across all sections.  The teaching team meets regularly to discuss teaching and learning activities and instructors are expected to attend these meetings.  This course has a significant amount of grading with quick turnaround for a couple of assignments.  For all assignments and final grades, instructors are expected to meet established deadlines. It is important to have consistency across all sections and the course coordinator is available to support new instructors.    
Quercus management: including learning and utilizing Quercus; the marking and grading of student work and the submission of grades to the course coordinator by the required date; adhering to the policies on teaching and holding classes when scheduled; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside of scheduled contact hours.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD in progress in social work with a preference given to candidates who have an MSW and are a Registered Social Worker (membership with the Ontario College of Social Workers and Social Service Workers). Thorough knowledge and in-depth understanding of Canadian mental health and health policy and services with a particular emphasis on Ontario; knowledge and social work practical experience with the health and mental health policy process.
qualifications_preferred: PhD in progress in social work with a preference given to candidates who have an MSW and are a Registered Social Worker (membership with the Ontario College of Social Workers and Social Service Workers). Thorough knowledge and in-depth understanding of Canadian mental health and health policy and services with a particular emphasis on Ontario; knowledge and social work practical experience with the health and mental health policy process.

One TA to cover both duties/terms preferred.

Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position. Solid background in Computer Science and Software Engineering. Excellent communication skills, ability to supervise student development teams. Knowledge of object-oriented design principles, design patterns, modelling in UML, software architecture. Interested candidates will be invited for a brief interview with the course instructor.  

These paid positions are open only to University of Toronto Students who have demonstrated a sound knowledge of the relevant subject matter and who have the ability to impart that knowledge to other students. duties: Duties include: attending two lectures per week throughout the term to support active learning; attending two weekly meetings to plan the  week’s studio activities and to debrief first round of studios; attending a day long orientation session for all instructors at the beginning of term (date TBA, likely late August); supporting two, 2-hour studios for the duration of the course; and participating in studio planning, revision, and discussion; invigilating one supervised test scheduled during the Engineering Science midterm timeslot (Monday 9-11 or Thursday 9-11); evaluating and providing detailed feedback on up to seven assignments (both group and individual), and attending benchmarking meeting(s) for assignment grading; holding consultations with students to help them complete and improve their assignments, and develop as writers and presenters; possibly assessing a final presentation during a makeup Thursday Studio time on Monday December 9 from 9–11 or on makeup Monday, which falls on Wednesday December 4, if scheduled for any Thursday Studios(still TBD); and having the ability to convert to online duties if required.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should have at least a Master’s degree in an appropriate discipline (such as, but not limited to, Communication, English, Engineering, Education, Technology Studies) with strong written and oral communication skills, and a demonstrated commitment to teaching communication and demonstrated ability to work as part of a team.
qualifications_preferred: include TESL or other training/certification in second-language instruction at the university level, and familiarity with engineering communication practices, and strong performance as an instructor in Praxis I or II. Flexible availability for studio and benchmarking meetings is also preferred.
salery: In accordance with the current CUPE 3902, Unit 1 collective agreement, the rate of pay applicable for course instructors will be $9,094.13 (excludes vacation pay) per half course and $18,188.26 (excludes vacation pay) per full course.

experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

Tutorials (Studios) T 13–15, W 12–14, W 16–18, R 12–14 (lecturers are responsible for two each week, schedule TBD).  

Weekly Teaching Team meeting M 16–17.  

Weekly Debrief Meeting T 15–16.

duties:
Coordination and delivery of support for student professional language development, teamwork, and overall experience in ESC101. This includes:Attending a day-long orientation session for all Praxis instructors at the beginning of the fall term (date TBA, likely late August) 

As needed to stay current with course content, attending lectures or reviewing lecture recordings 

Attending weekly teaching team planning and studio debrief meetings (see course schedule) 

Designing appropriate support activities and mechanisms for first-year Engineering Science students enrolled in ESC101 

Visiting all studios on an ongoing basis to check in with students/teams and with Studio Instructors 

Liaising regularly with the Course Instructors, likely in a weekly planning meeting, and additionally as needed 

Ongoing monitoring and follow-up with students identified as needing professional language support 

Ongoing monitoring and follow-up with individual students and teams, as needed, in collaboration with the Course Instructors and other teamwork support resources, to support the students’ teamwork experience 

Ongoing monitoring of assignments, including benchmarking and grading calibration, and collaboration with Course Instructors to design appropriate support activities 

As needed, meeting with individual students or teams outside of class time 

Must have the ability to adapt to different communication instruction activities and move online if required
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

qualifications_preferred: include a PhD in an appropriate discipline (as above); and previous experience benchmarking assignments and calibrating assignment grading across multiple assessors. previous experience and strong performance as a Studio Instructor in Praxis I.

application_procedure: submit cover letter, academic record to d.ballyk@utoronto.ca
duties: meetings with Course Director, preparation for lab demonstration, lab demonstration, holding in-lab review sessions prior to assessments, invigilation of assessments, marking of tests, uploading of grades
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful completion of an undergraduate course or courses in human gross anatomy, histology and neuroanatomy at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required
qualifications_preferred: Experience teaching human gross anatomy, histology, and neuroanatomy is an asset.

job_title: Introduction to Medicine, Concepts, Patients, and Communities - 1, Concepts, Patients, and Communities -2
application_procedure: Please submit CV and cover letter (including statement of teaching experience(s) and previous evaluations (if applicable)) to Dr. Danielle Bentley via email, danielle.bentley@utoronto.ca
duties:
Basic Training / Attendance at onboarding meeting with Course Instructor.
Leading in-person, hands-on, human anatomy laboratories that focus on the gross anatomy of the back, thorax, abdomen, pelvis. 
Demonstrating dissection of human cadavers. 
Demonstrating gross anatomy using models, bones, and human cadaveric prosections. 
Meeting with the Course Instructor prior to every in-person laboratory and in-person MAPS session. 
Participating in TA training sessions.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Successful completion of a practical course in human gross anatomy at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required. 

Experience in human cadaveric dissection is required.
qualifications_preferred:
Experience teaching practical human gross anatomy is an asset. 

An MD degree, completed or in progress, from the University of Toronto or equivalent is an asset.

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, C.V. (including statement of teaching experience(s) and previous evaluations (if applicable)) no later than August 5th, 2024 to email: Tania Alexson, Ph.D., Assistant Professor, Teaching Stream (tania.alexson@utoronto.ca)
duties: Basic Training / Attendance at onboarding meeting with Course Instructor Leading in-person, hands-on, human anatomy laboratories that focus on the gross anatomy of the musculoskeletal system; a total of 3. Demonstrating gross anatomy using models, bones, and human cadaveric prosections. Meeting with the Course Director prior to every in-person laboratory.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful completion of a practical course in human gross anatomy at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required.
qualifications_preferred: Experience working with prosected human cadaveric materials in regards to the musculskeletal system is an asset. Experience as a teaching assistant for a course in human gross anatomy is also an asset. Furthermore, an MD degree, completed or in progress, from the University of Toronto or equivalent is an asset.

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, C.V. (including statement of teaching experience(s) and previous evaluations (if applicable)) no later than August 5th, 2024 to email: Tania Alexson, Ph.D., Assistant Professor, Teaching Stream (tania.alexson@utoronto.ca)
duties: Basic Training / Attendance at onboarding meeting with Course Instructor Leading in-person, hands-on, human anatomy laboratories that focus on the gross anatomy of the nervous system; a total of 3 in-person labs. This will include one dissection, but the majority will be completed by demonstrating neuroanatomy using models and human cadaveric prosections. In addition, leading 4 online virtual laboratories with an emphasis on pathways and case studies. Meeting with the Course Director prior to every in-person laboratory.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful completion of a practical course in human gross anatomy with a strong neuroanatomy unit or a course dedicated to human neuroanatomy (eg. HMB 320S) at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required.
qualifications_preferred: Experience in human cadaveric dissection of the human brain is an asset. Experience teaching neuroanatomy is also asset. Furthermore, an MD degree, completed or in progress, from the University of Toronto or equivalent is an asset.

application_procedure: Please submit CV and cover letter (including statement of teaching experience(s) and previous evaluations (if applicable)) to Dr. Danielle Bentley via email, danielle.bentley@utoronto.ca
duties:
Attendance at Meeting with Course Instructor.
Preparation and Instruction of Review Sessions and Q&A Sessions. 
Marking of Course Assessments (i.e. in-class case studies, written term tests, final exam).
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Previous completion of a full-year Human Anatomy course is required.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience as a Human Anatomy TA is an asset.

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure:
Apply on the Electrical and Computer Engineering on-line TA Database. Instructions and link are posted on the ECE TA web page: https://www.ece.utoronto.ca/faculty/career-opportunities/ or directly at: https://eceta2.ece.toronto.edu/.  Incoming students who do not have a UTORid yet should be able to use their JOINid to log in.

 If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties: Duties may include  running the laboratory experiments in the ECE Energy Systems Labs, and marking tutorial/laboratory work, problem sets, tests and examinations.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Knowledge and experience with power electronic converters. Knowledge and experience with EV sub-systems including motor drives, batteries and charging systems. Experience with high voltage systems and safety (ECE314 or equivalent).

application_procedure: Applications accepted online https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/cms/app/ta
duties: The successful applicant will be in charge of all aspects related to auto-grading student work. This may involve working on the assignment starter code and modify it to ensure it properly interacts with the automarking system as well as addressing students' concerns about their auto-grading results. Other duties as required by the course.  Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
This position is specifically dedicated to supporting, running, and improving the automarkers used to grade assignments for CSCA08H3F. Previous experience running and using the automarkers is required.
Previous experience with the assignments and exercises for CSCA08 is required. These paid positions are open only to University of Toronto Students who have demonstrated a sound knowledge of the relevant subject matter and who have the ability to impart that knowledge to other students. All contracts are by session and extend for four months each as per the length of each session. Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please submit a Unit 1 Course Instructor Application Form, Resume and Teaching Dossier to the MIE Undergraduate Office by email at ugservices@mie.utoronto.ca no later than August 8, 2024 at 11:59PM (Eastern Time). The Course Instructor Application Form can be found on the MIE Careers page here: https://www.mie.utoronto.ca/faculty-staff/careers/. Applicants must include full contact information of their supervisor, plus two U of T employees (faculty or staff) who can testify to the teaching skills of the applicant.  The appointment will be made at the earliest possible time before the commencement of classes by the Associate Chair (Undergraduate) of the Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering.  No other offers or notices of the outcome of applications are authorized by the Department.  Final availability of the position is contingent upon final course determination, enrolment, budgetary considerations, and the final determination of assignments flowing from Article 14:03 of the Collective Agreement.
duties: Preparation of lectures and course materials; delivery of lectures; supervision of Teaching Assistants; setting and marking of tests and exams; evaluation of final grades; contact with students.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants should have a strong record of presenting lectures or acting as a teaching assistant.  Applicants must be able to demonstrate considerable depth of knowledge and experience in the subject area.  All applicants should have excellent communication skills - both oral and written. Professional Engineer (P.Eng.) or Limited License (LEL) is strongly preferred. Engineering Intern (EIT) is also acceptable.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

application_procedure: 1. See Course Instructor job postings and application procedures information on the department website at https://www.economics.utoronto.ca/index.php/index/graduate/gciOpenings and https://unit1.hrandequity.utoronto.ca/. 2. If interested, please submit an application to the Joseph Steinberg, Teaching Coordinator (https://uoft.me/ecocourseinstructor). On your application, please specify which course instructor position(s) you are applying for in order of preference. Also submit in PDF format a copy of your resume along with a note (email is fine) from your thesis supervisor indicating s/he is satisfied with your program progress and supports your application.
duties: 1.  Preparation and delivery of lectures in the course. 2.  Supervision of T.A(s) assigned to course. 3.  Preparation, supervision and grading of tests and examinations in accordance with University regulations as described in the Faculty of Arts & Science Academic Handbook. 4.  Providing scheduled office hours for academic counseling of students. 5. All or majority of duties are planned to be in-person, but they may also have online component.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrolment as full-time student in the Ph.D. program in Economics at the U of T
qualifications_preferred: Completion of all PhD course requirements including 2nd year paper preferred
salery: Rate of pay: Current rates as of January 1, 2024 - $9094.13 (per half course, excluding vacation pay). Course Instructors (first time CI’s) - effective January 1, 2024 - $10163.28 (per half course, excluding vacation pay).  Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure:
Applicants must submit a cover letter and resume, clearly indicating any previous invigilation experience. University of Toronto student number and confirmation of registration status on ACORN is required. Confirmation of availability for the period outlined above is required.  Applicants must also confirm availability to invigilate weekday evening and weekend examinations.  
Applications should be addressed to the Assistant Dean, Graduate Programs and must be submitted by email to gpllm@utoronto.ca.
Please note that incomplete applications will not be considered
duties:
Incumbents will supervise the writing of tests and examinations by students enrolled in the Global Professional Master of Laws (GPLLM) program at the Faculty of Law.  Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: maintaining the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental and university policies and procedures, verifying student identification, maintaining the confidentiality of student and text/exam information, monitoring test/exam time allotments, handling student concerns/problems and escalating any issues to the Assistant Director, GPLLM and/or Assistant Dean, Graduate Programs, documenting and responding to anomalous situations, gathering completed tests/exams and returning them to the program team, scanning handwritten exams for distribution to instructors, maintaining required administrative records.

Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled.  As a result, minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed.  Most exams are written on evenings (e.g., 5:00 to 10:00 p.m.) and weekends (12:00 to 5:00 p.m.), and applicants are required to be able to accommodate invigilating exams that are held according to these schedules during both mid-term and final examination periods.  See note below re: need to confirm availability to invigilate weekday evening and weekend exams at the time of application.
qualifications:
This position is open to NEW applicants. Applicants who have previously invigilated exams in the GPLLM Program needn’t re-apply. Applicants must be currently registered as students pursuing a degree at the University of Toronto and must continue to be registered as students throughout the duration of the appointment (thereby maintaining their eligibility for CUPE 3902 Unit 1 work).  Any status change must be communicated to the GPLLM program immediately, so that eligibility to continue in the appointment can be determined. This is an on-campus, in-person position. Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts.  Experience invigilating tests and exams is strongly preferred.  Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion. 

Skills (listed alphabetically): Ability to manage and resolve emergency, difficult or sensitive situations effectively while maintaining boundaries, ability to demonstrate integrity and professionalism while remaining calm under pressure, communication (both oral and written), initiative, interpersonal, organizations, problem solving and resourcefulness, attention to detail, situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities, understanding and the ability to apply relevant university and government policies, procedures and legislation, ability to collaborate with others and work in a team setting.
Relevant Criterion: 
Students enrolled in the LLM, MSL or GPLLM programs at the Faculty of Law are ineligible to apply for these positions.  

Preference will be given to applicants in the Faculty of Law’s SJD program. Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
salery: $34.22 + $1/hour worked on Saturday and Sunday shifts + 4% vacation pay. Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

job_title: Innovative Technologies and Organizations in Global Energy Systems
application_procedure: Those interested should submit a letter of application and current cv by email to Ms. Sharon Brown, Associate Director, Cross-Disciplinary Programs Office: s.brown@utoronto.ca
duties: The instructor will prepare for and deliver 12 weeks of lectures and tutorials; set assignments as appropriate; set and grade assignments and midterms; set and grade a final assessment; collate and submit marks; handle petitions after final marks have been submitted; communicating with students both inside and outside of class times.  May be required to provide a deferred exam.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Ph.D. candidate or Postdoctoral Fellow in the area of global engineering; candidate should have knowledge of energy production and delivery, corporate strategy, entrepreneurship, global innovation; previous experience teaching a similar course is highly desirable, including exposure to teaching business case studies. Familiarity with engineering concepts a strong asset, as is direct familiarity with a range of smaller, entrepreneurial energy companies and organizations in North America and globally.
qualifications_preferred: Ph.D. candidate or Postdoctoral Fellow in the area of global engineering; candidate should have knowledge of energy production and delivery, corporate strategy, entrepreneurship, global innovation; previous experience teaching a similar course is highly desirable, including exposure to teaching business case studies. Familiarity with engineering concepts a strong asset, as is direct familiarity with a range of smaller, entrepreneurial energy companies and organizations in North America and globally.

application_procedure: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/ctl/app/ta
duties:
Duties may include: holding in-person and virtual office hours for CTL’s Math and Statistics Support program; helping students with their calculus courses; delivering workshops and exam review seminars in person and in an online setting; providing virtual one-to-one sessions; responding to student queries by email and Quercus Forum discussions; filming educational materials, if there is a student demand for it; and helping with MSS initiatives and promotion such as U(t)-Mathazine and Math in Action Journal. For Fall 2024 and Winter 2025, we anticipate that some duties will be completed on campus. Teaching assistants should have access to a stable, high-speed internet line, a computer with a working webcam and microphone and a quiet workspace. 
To complete the application, please upload the following documents: 
1. Cover Letter (indicate student status at the begginning of the term, eg. 1st Yr M. Sc Program)
2. Curriculum Vitae or Resume
3. Transcript (unofficial copy is accepted)
4. Contact information of THREE references.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A solid knowledge of Calculus courses in undergraduate programs at the University of Toronto, Scarborough campus; excellent communication skills; minimum of 1-2 years of teaching experience or TA experience in the field of Mathematics.
qualifications_preferred: An average grade of A- in four C or D level math courses and familiarity with web conferencing tools such as Teams and Zoom would be an asset.
salery:
January 1, 2024: Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $51.93 per hour 
January 1, 2025: Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $52.97 per hour

For Fall 2024 and Winter 2025, we anticipate that some duties will be completed on campus. application_procedure: Applicants should send the requested documents below to the attention of Prof. Arsalan Kahnemuyipour, Chair, Department of Language Studies, UTM via email to jobslanguagestudies.utm@utoronto.ca by the posted deadline: 1. DLS Unit 1 Job Application form (Please submit your information here: https://forms.office.com/r/94cuaqRR5T, then "print to PDF" to save a copy of the submission), 2. Cover letter (this should include a statement on the applicant's background and experience with respect to the posted qualifications), and 3. Current academic CV.
duties: Assist course instructor with TA management and course administration, mentor and provide feedback to other TAs. (NOTE: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be online synchronous. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated ability in the specific area of the course (gastronomy, history, cultural studies, diaspora studies, experiential learning) is required. Native, or near-native, fluency in written and spoken Italian is required.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate-level research in Italian studies is preferred. Experience in this course or a similar course is preferred.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

The TA should also have direct experience in one or more areas of EV batteries - manufacturing, cooling, recycling/recovery, safety, etc. at the undergraduate level or above (has taken relevant courses in the past).
salery: $51.93 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
This in-person course covers fundamental topics from machine learning, and related foundational topics including the use of Python, its ML packages, and the process of using data for making predictive and inferential models. The course is structured with both weekly lectures and tutorials/Q&A sessions. The students complete eight reading assignments and four ML projects for this course in addition to a midterm assessment and a final exam.

The head-TA will be responsible for all duties listed in the DDAH form.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Minimum Qualifications:
• An undergraduate (or preferably a graduate) degree in a computational field, including but not limited to computer science, engineering, statistics, mathematics, natural sciences, and data science.
• Demonstrable experience of leading a successful team
• Understanding of and interest in machine learning.
• Strong communications skills and interest in supporting the learning of students
• Strong programming and computer skills (Python)
• Must be capable of working independently.
Relevant Criteria:
The ideal candidate for this position must also demonstrate:
1. Knowledge of machine learning and as evidenced by high grades in relevant courses and/or related projects/past TA or head-TA work experience
2. Familiarity with machine learning libraries in Python (sklearn, pytorch, numpy, pandas, etc.)
3. Experience in evaluating machine learning projects and working as an effective team leader.
4. Experience in running interactive Python tutorials and Q&A (troubleshooting) sessions
5. Desire to stay current with the fast-paced development of machine learning 
6. Availability on campus for both tutorial sections of MIE 370 throughout the semester

To apply for the head-TA position, please submit CV (resume) highlighting relevant experience (past TA and/or head-TA experience) and a brief statement on why you are suitable for this head-TA position.
salery: $51.93 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
This in-person course covers fundamental topics from machine learning, and related foundational topics including the use of Python, its ML packages, and the process of using data for making predictive and inferential models. The course is structured with both weekly lectures and tutorials/Q&A sessions. The students complete eight reading assignments and four ML projects for this course in addition to a midterm assessment and a final exam.

The TA will be responsible for all duties listed in the DDAH form.

To apply for a TA position, please submit CV (resume) highlighting relevant experience (past TA experience) and a brief statement on why you are suitable for this position.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Minimum Qualifications:
• An undergraduate (or preferably a graduate) degree in a computational field, including but not limited to computer science, engineering, statistics, mathematics, natural sciences, and data science.
• Understanding of and interest in machine learning.
• Strong communications skills and interest in supporting the learning of students
• Strong programming and computer skills (Python)
• Must be capable of working independently.
Relevant Criteria:
The ideal candidate for this position must also demonstrate:
1. Knowledge of machine learning and as evidenced by high grades in relevant courses and/or related projects/work experience
2. Familiarity with machine learning libraries in Python (sklearn, pytorch, numpy, pandas, etc.)
3. Experience in evaluating machine learning projects and working as an effective team member.
4. Experience in (or desire for) running interactive Python Q&A (troubleshooting) sessions
5. Desire to stay current with the fast-paced development of machine learning 
6. Availability on campus for both tutorial sections of MIE 370 throughout the semester
salery: $51.93 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties: Maintain and grade assignments, assist students in office hours, and teach tutorials/labs on theories and technologies related to decision support including information retrieval, machine learning, recommender systems, data science and data mining, text analytics, and social network analysis.  Proficiency in Python, scipy, numpy, pandas, nltk and sklearn required.  TAs will grade assignments and participate in exam grading.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Strong Python coding skills, proficiency with github, knowledge of machine learning and Python toolkits (scipy, numpy, pandas, nltk, and sklearn).
salery: $51.93 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

duties:
Teaching Assistants will work as Teamwork and Communication Instructors (TCIs) and be required to conduct tutorial workshops alongside a disciplinary TA, work with students (both individually and in teams) and grade assignments, as well as work with the coordinator and other TAs on curriculum development. This position may require TCI's to lead tutorials throughout the term; TCI's are always suppored by the other TA in the tutorial workshops. 

Duties include: Weekly Two-hour tutorials Winter term. weekly/bi-weekly meetings with MIE coordinator and other TAs to prepare tutorial materials and benchmark assignments. Grading written work and oral presentations. Ability to convert to online duties if required.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should have at least an undergraduate degree and currently be enrolled in a Masters or PhD program in engineering (Mechanical or Industrial preferred but not essential).
qualifications_preferred: Candidates must have strong written and oral communication skills, teamwork, leadership skills and a demonstrated commitment to teaching communication and teamwork. In addition, assets would include familiarity with engineering communication practices and/or training in second-language instruction at the university level.  This course is team-taught, the ability to work as part of a team is essential, both at the individual tutorial level and as part of a larger teaching team. Experience as a student or TA in the first year foundation course, Engineering Strategies and Practice or any other engineering communication courses, is desirable.
salery: $52.97 per hour + vacation pay (as of Jan 1, 2025). Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

job_title: Introduction to Women and Gender Studies

YOU MUST USE THE FOLLOWING FOR YOUR SUBJECT LINE: APPLICATION: COURSE CODE: LAST NAME. duties:
Review readings and lecture materials 
Periodic meetings with the professor 
Mark essays and record marks 
Hold office hours the week after assignments are returned   

Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated interest in Asia-Pacific and/or South Asian Studies and strong performance in a social sciences or humanities graduate program is required.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to candidates with grounded research experience in East, Southeast, and/or South Asian Studies who are excelling in their respective disciplinary graduate program, and those that evince a multi-regional social science perspective that includes critical approaches to area studies, public culture and markets, ethnography and/or historical studies. First consideration will be given to senior PhD students at the University of Toronto, but strong MA students are invited to apply. TA experience is preferred.

application_procedure: Applicants must submit a cover letter, C.V. or resume, and a list of references by July 31st, 2024. Applications should be sent via email to the Robert Gillespie Academic Skills Centre at academicskills.utm@utoronto.ca with the subject title: PELS Unit 1 Job Posting.
duties: As a Teaching Assistant for the Robert Gillespie Academic Skills Centre’s (RGASC) Professional English Language Skills (PELS), the TA will perform the following duties: monitoring PELS discussion boards, facilitating participation in student hours and events (in person), and marking assessments using answer keys
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must be currently enrolled as a Master or PhD graduate student at the University of Toronto. Applicants should have at least two years of experience as a Teaching Assistant at the University of Toronto. Applicants should have experience and facility with administering Quercus sites. Applicants must have the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with PELS administrators, students, and faculty.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to a student who has completed PELS or is interested in helping students with academic English language learning and study skills development and has an interest in intercultural communication strategies and linguistic diversity. An academic background in writing and communication or experience in writing instruction (as a student learner or teaching assistant) is an asset but not required – training will be provided.

duties: Providing feedback and grading assignments, designing and facilitating in-class learning activities, supporting student learning by answering questions outside of class time, and modelling good leadership behaviour in all interactions with students. experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

qualifications_preferred: Preferred experience with Troost ILead leadership courses or programming.
